standard_metadata.standard_description: Solve multistep word problems posed with whole numbers and having whole-number answers using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be interpreted. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Represent multi-step word problems using equations

question.content: A bakery has been selling out of their most popular type of cookie. For that cookie, the bakers decide to bake their usual  $300$ cookies plus $120$ extra. Each pan they bake holds $18$ cookies.    **Which equation can we use to find $\greenD{p}$, the number of pans of cookies, the bakers will need to bake?**

hints.content: We can add to find the total number of cookies the bakers need to make.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonD{300}+\blueE{120}=\text{total cookies}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is larger and is labeled 300. The second part is labeled 120. A curved bracket above the first part is labeled usual cookies. A curved bracket above the second part is labeled extra cookies. A curved bracket below the entire diagram is labeled total cookies.

hints.content: Each pan holds $18$ cookies. So next we can divide by $18$ to find out how many pans it will take to bake all those cookies.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of unequal lengths, a first tape labeled 300 plus 120 in parentheses and a shorter second tape labeled 18. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total cookies. A curved bracket below the second tape is the same width of the first tape and is labeled p pans of 18 cookies.

hints.content: We can use this equation to find $\greenD{p}$, the number of pans of cookies, the bakers will need to bake:  $(300+120)\div\purpleD{18}=\greenE{p}$

question.content: Rita got up early this morning to hike into the mountains and watch the sun rise.   Rita climbed $47$ meters in height from the starting point. Then she went steeply downhill, losing $36$ meters in height. Finally, Rita climbed $10$ more meters in height to the ledge where she watched the sun rise.  **Which equation can we use to find $\purpleD{h}$, the number of meters higher the ledge was than the starting point?**

hints.content: Rita started by going up $47$ meters in height from the starting point. We can subtract to find her height after she went down $36$ meters in height.     [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{47}-\maroonD{36}=\greenE{\text{height above start after }2\text{ parts of hike}}$

images.alt: A vertical number line labeled, from bottom to top 0 to 50 with minor tick marks every 5 units and labeled major tick marks every 10 units. The 0 tick mark is also labeled starting point. An arrow labeled minus 36 jumps down the number line from labeled Point 47 to an unlabeled point above tick mark 10.

hints.content: Then we can add the $10$ meter gain  in height from the final part of the hike.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{47-36}+\goldE{10}=\purpleD{\text{height of ledge above start}}$

images.alt: A vertical number line labeled, from bottom to top 0 to 50 with minor tick marks every 5 units and labeled major tick marks every 10 units. The 0 tick mark is also labeled starting point. An arrow labeled plus 10 jumps up the number line from a point labeled 47 minus 36, located above tick mark 10, to a point labeled ledge, located above tick mark 20.

hints.content: We can use this equation to find $\purpleD{h}$, the number of meters higher the ledge was than the starting point:  $47-36+10=\purpleD{h}$

question.content: A teacher bought $580$ straws for their class to use to build straw towers. They divided the straws evenly among $6$ groups. In a cupboard, they found $25$ more straws to give each group.  **Which equation can we use to find $\greenE{n}$, the number of straws each group received?**

hints.content: We can divide to find the number of straws each group will get from the straws the teacher bought.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{580}\div 6=\maroonD{\text{bought straws per group}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of unequal length. The first tape is labeled 580. A curved bracket above the tape is labeled straws the teacher bought. The second tape is divided into 6 equal parts. A curved bracket below 1 of the 6 parts is labeled bought straws per group.

hints.content: We can add to find the total number of straws per group.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonD{580 \div 6} + \purpleD{25} = \greenE{\text{total straws per group}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is larger and is labeled 580 divided by 6. The second part is labeled 25. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled total straws per group. A curved bracket below the first part is labeled bought straws per group. A curved bracket below the second part is labeled found straws per group.

hints.content: We can use this equation to find $\greenE{n}$, the number of straws each group got:  $580\div6+25=\greenE{n}$

question.content: Will brought a tray with $42$ veggie sticks home from his job as a caterer. He took $18$ carrot sticks off  the tray. Half of the remaining sticks are peppers, and the other half are celery.  **Which equation can we use to find the number of pepper sticks $(\greenD{p})$ on the tray?**

hints.content: We can subtract to find the number of sticks still on the tray after Will takes off the carrot sticks.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonD{42}-\blueE{18}=\purpleD{\text{sticks left on tray}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 42 and the second tape divided into 2 unequal parts, the first part shorter and labeled 18 and the second part labeled question mark. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total veggie sticks. A curved bracket below the first part of the second tape is labeled sticks Will took off. A curved bracket below the second part of the second tape is labeled sticks left on tray.

hints.content: Half of the sticks left on the tray are peppers. We can divide the remaining sticks into $2$ equal groups.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{(42-18)} \div 2 = \greenE{\text{pepper sticks}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 42 minus 18 in parentheses and the second tape divided into 2 equal parts each labeled p. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled sticks left on tray. A curved bracket below the 1 of the 2 parts of the second tape is labeled pepper sticks.

hints.content: $(42 - 18) \div 2 = \greenD{p}$

question.content: One tube holds $3$ tennis balls. Jenna filled $5$ tubes and had $1$ ball left over.   **Which equation could we use to find $\blueE{n}$, the number of tennis balls?**

hints.content: We can multiply to find the number of tennis balls in the tubes.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\goldE{5} \times \maroonE{3} = \purpleD{\text{balls in tubes}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 5 equal parts. Each part is labeled 3. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled tennis balls in tubes. A curved bracket below the entire tape diagram is labeled 5 tubes with 3 balls each.

hints.content: We can add the $1$ extra ball to find the total number of tennis balls.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{5 \times 3} + \redE{1} = \blueE{\text{total balls}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is larger and labeled 5 times 3. The second part is labeled 1. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled total balls. A curved bracket below the first part is labeled balls in tubes. A curved bracket below the second part is labeled ball left over.

hints.content: We can use this equation to find $\blueE{n}$, the number of tennis balls:  $5 \times3+1=\blueE{n}$

question.content: Franklin ordered $6$ boxes of ice pops for a pool party. Each box had $12$ ice pops. There will be $24$ guests at the party.   **Which equation can we use to find $\greenD{p}$, the number of ice pops each person can have if the guests share them equally?**

hints.content: We can multiply to find the total number of ice pops.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\goldE{6}\times \maroonD{12} = \blueE{\text{total ice pops}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 6 equal parts. Each part is labeled 12. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled total ice pops. A curved bracket below the entire tape diagram is labeled 6 boxes with 12 ice pops each.

hints.content: Next, we can divide to find out how many ice pops each person can have.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{6\times 12} \div \purpleD{24}=\greenE{\text{ice pops per guest}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length. The first label is labeled 6 times 12. The second tape is divided into 24 equal parts. Each part is labeled p. A curved bracket above the entire first tape is labeled total ice pops. A curved bracket below the entire second tape is labeled 24 guests with p ice pops each.

hints.content: $6\times 12\div 24=\greenE{p}$

question.content: A building has $6$ homes per floor and $3$ floors. On the first floor, there are $4$ penguins per home. On the second and third floor, there are $3$ penguins per home.  **Which equation can we use to find $\maroonD{p}$, the total number of penguins living in the building?**

hints.content: We can multiply to find the number of penguins on each floor.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{4 \times 6} = \text{penguins on first floor}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 6 equal parts. Each part is labeled 4. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled penguins on first floor. A curved bracket below the entire tape diagram is labeled 6 homes with 4 penguins each.

hints.content: [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{3 \times 6} = \text{penguins on second floor}$    [[☃ image 2]]  $\greenE{3 \times 6} = \text{penguins on third floor}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 6 equal parts. Each part is labeled 3. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled penguins on second floor. A curved bracket below the entire tape diagram is labeled 6 homes with 3 penguins each.

A tape diagram divided into 6 equal parts. Each part is labeled 3. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled penguins on third floor. A curved bracket below the entire tape diagram is labeled 6 homes with 3 penguins each.

hints.content: We can add to find the total number of penguins.    [[☃ image 1]]  $(\blueE{4 \times 6)} + \purpleD{(3 \times 6)} + \greenE{(3 \times 6}) = \maroonD{\text{total penguins}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 3 parts. The last two parts are equal in size, but the first part is slightly larger. The first part is labeled 4 times 6 in parentheses. The second and third part are each labeled 3 times 6 in parentheses. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled total penguins. A curved bracket below the first part is labeled first floor penguins. A curved bracket below the second part is labeled second floor penguins. A curved bracket below the third part is labeled third floor penguins.

hints.content: We can use this equation to find $\greenE{p}$, the total number of penguins living in the building:  $(4 \times 6) + (3 \times 6) + (3 \times 6) = \maroonD{p}$

question.content: A cooking class had $62$ students. One group of $35$ students chose to cook spaghetti. The teacher divided the remaining students into groups of $9$ to make bread sticks. Each of those groups cooked $24$ bread sticks.  **Which equation can we use to find $\redE{b}$, the number of bread sticks the class cooked?**

hints.content: We can subtract to find the number of students cooked bread sticks.   [[☃ image 1]]    $\purpleD{62}-\blueE{35}=\maroonD{\text{students who cooked bread sticks}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first tape labeled 62 and a second tape with 2 unequal parts, one part labeled 35 and the other has no label. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled students in class. A second curved bracket below the part labeled 35 is labeled students who cooked spaghetti. A third curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled students who cooked bread sticks.

hints.content: We can divide to see how many groups cooked bread sticks.   [[☃ image 1]]   $\maroonD{(62-35)} \div \greenD{9} = \goldE{\text{groups who cooked bread sticks}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of unequal length, a first tape labeled 62 minus 35 in parentheses and a second tape labeled 9. A curved bracket above the entire first tape is labeled students who cooked bread sticks. Another curved bracket below the second tape is the same width of the first tape and is labeled question mark groups of 9 students.

hints.content: We can multiply to find the total number of bread sticks.  [[☃ image 1]]   $\goldE{(62-35) \div 9} \times \tealE{24} = \redE{\text{total bread sticks}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 3 equal parts. Each part is labeled 24. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled total bread sticks. A curved bracket below the entire tape diagram is labeled 62 minus 35 in parentheses divided by 9 groups with 24 bread sticks each.

hints.content: $(62-35) \div 9 \times 24 = \redE{b}$

question.content: There were $47$ ducks swimming in a pond. A dog jumped into the pond and scared $29$ of the ducks away. After the dog got out, $5$ groups of $3$ ducks returned to the pond.  **Which equation can we use to find $\greenE{d}$, the number of ducks in the pond after the dog got out?**

hints.content: We can subtract to find the number of ducks that remained in the pond after the dog jumped in.     [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{47}-\blueE{29}=\maroonD{\text{ducks still in pond}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal lengths, the first tape labeled 47 and a second tape with 2 unequal parts, one part labeled 29 and the other has no label. A curved bracket above the entire first tape is labeled ducks in pond at start. A curved bracket below the part labeled 29 is labeled ducks scared away. A second curved bracket below the part with no label is labeled ducks still in pond.

hints.content: We can multiply to find the number of ducks that returned.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\tealE{3} \times \goldE{5} = \redE{\text{ducks that returned}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 5 equal parts. Each part is labeled 3. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled ducks that returned. A curved bracket below the entire tape diagram is labeled 5 groups of 3 ducks.

hints.content: We can add to find the final number of ducks.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonD{(47-29)}+\redE{(5 \times 3)}=\greenE{\text{ducks in the pond after the dog got out}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is larger and is labeled 47 minus 29 in parentheses. The second part is labeled 5 times 3 in parentheses. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled ducks in pond after the dog got out. A curved bracket below the first part is labeled ducks still in pond. A curved bracket below the second part is labeled ducks that returned.

hints.content: We can use this equation to find $\greenE{d}$, the number of ducks in the pond after the dog got out.  $(47-29)+(5 \times 3)=\greenE{d}$

question.content: Alena had $4$ packs of gum with $6$ pieces of gum in each pack. Hugh had $3$ packs of gum with $5$ pieces in each. Alena and Hugh have $19$ pieces of gum left.   **Which equation can we use to find $\greenD{p}$, the number of pieces of gum Alena and Hugh chewed?**

hints.content: We can multiply to find the number of pieces of gum each person has.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{4 \times 6} = \text{Alena's pieces}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 4 equal parts. Each part is labeled 6. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled Alena's gum pieces at start. A curved bracket below the entire tape diagram is labeled 4 packs with 6 pieces of gum each.

hints.content: [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonD{3 \times 5} = \text{Hugh's pieces}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 3 equal parts. Each part is labeled 5. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled Hugh's gum pieces at start. A curved bracket below the entire tape diagram is labeled 3 packs with 5 pieces of gum each.

hints.content: We can add to find the total number of pieces of gum they started with.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{(4 \times 6)} + \maroonD{(3 \times 5)} = \purpleD{\text{total pieces}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is larger and labeled 4 times 6 in parentheses. The second part is labeled 3 times 5 in parentheses. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled total pieces of gum at start. A curved bracket below the first part is labeled Alena's pieces. A curved bracket below the second part is labeled Hugh's pieces.

hints.content: We can subtract the $19$ pieces they have left to find out how many pieces they chewed.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{(4 \times 6)+ (3 \times 5)} -\goldE{19} = \greenE{\text{pieces chewed}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length. The first tape is labeled 4 times 6 in parentheses plus 3 times 5 in parentheses. The second tape is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is shorter and is labeled 19. The second part is labeled p. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total pieces of gum at start. A curved bracket below the first part of the second tape is labeled pieces left. A curved bracket below the second part of the second tape is labeled pieces chewed.

hints.content: $(4\times6) + (3 \times 5) - 19=\greenE{p}$

question.content: The tallest water slide is $49$ meters tall. Phineas and Ferb want to build a slide that is $5$ meters taller. They build the slide in sections that are each $6$ meters tall.  **Match each equation to what it means in this context.**

hints.content: Let's build expressions from what we know.  If we add or subtract before we multiply or divide, we need parentheses around the addition or subtraction part.  We also use parentheses when we do a step on the right before a step on the left.
The tallest water slide is $49$ meters tall.  $\purpleD{a}=\purpleD{49}=\purpleD{\text{tallest slide height}}$
We can add to figure out how many meters tall the slide needs to be.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{b}=\purpleD{49}+\redE{5}=\blueE{\text{new slide height}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is larger and is labeled 49. The second part is labeled 5. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled new slide height. A curved bracket below the first part is labeled tallest slide height. A curved bracket below the second part is labeled extra meters.

hints.content: We can divide to find out how many $6$ meter sections Phineas and Ferb need.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\goldE{c}=\blueE{(49+5)} \div \maroonD{6} = \goldE{\text{number of sections}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of unequal lengths, the first is larger and is labeled 49 plus 5 in parentheses, the second is labeled 6. A curved bracket above the entire first tape is labeled new slide height. Another curved bracket below the second tape is the same width of the first tape and is labeled question mark sections that are 6 meters long each.

hints.content: Equation | Meaning - | - $a=49$ | The height, in meters, of the tallest water slide $b=49+5$ | The height, in meters, of the slide Phineas and Ferb want to build $c=(49+5)\div 6$ | The number of sections they need to meet their goal

question.content: At a restaurant grand opening, a giant sandwich that was $352$ centimeters long was divided equally among $22$ people.  Clyde got one of the pieces, ate half, and saved half for later.  **Match each equation to what it means in this context.**

hints.content: Let's build expressions from what we know.
The giant sandwich was $352$ centimeters long.  $\blueE{a}=\blueE{352}=\blueE{\text{total sandwich length}}$
We can divide to find the length of sandwich each person received.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonD{b}=\blueE{352}\div 22 = \maroonD{\text{length of sandwich per person}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes equal in length, the first labeled 352 and the second divided into 22 equal parts each labeled question mark. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total length of sandwich in centimeters. A curved bracket below 1 of the 22 parts of the second tape is labeled length of sandwich per person.

hints.content: Clyde saved $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of his sandwich. We can divide the length of Clyde's sandwich into $2$ equal pieces.  [[☃ image 1]]  $c=\maroonD{352 \div 22} \div 2 = {\text{length Clyde saved}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length, the first labeled 352 divided by 22 and the second divided into 2 equal parts each labeled l. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled length of Clyde's sandwich. A curved bracket below the first part of the second tape is labeled length Clyde ate. A curved bracket below the second part of the second tape is labeled length Clyde saved.

hints.content: Equation | Meaning - | - $a=352$ | The length, in $\text{cm}$, of the whole sandwich $b=352\div 22$ | The length, in $\text{cm}$, of the sandwich per person $c=352 \div 22 \div 2$ | The length, in $\text{cm}$, of the part of the sandwich Clyde saved

question.content: Donald is giving his old rare coins to his grandchildren. He has $56$ coins and $8$ grandchildren, and he gives each grandchild the same number of coins. Each coin has a value of $\$18$.  **Match each equation to what it means in this context.**

hints.content: Let's build expressions from what we know.
Donald has $56$ coins.  $\maroonD{a}=\maroonD{56}=\maroonD{\text{total coins}}$
We can divide to find how many coins each grandchild gets.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{b}=\maroonD{56}\div 8 = \blueE{\text{coins per grandchild}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal lengths, the first tape labeled 56 and a second tape divided into 8 equal parts, each labeled question mark. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total coins. A curved bracket below 1 of the 8 parts of the second tape is labeled coins per grandchild.

hints.content: Then, we can multiply the number of coins each grandchild gets by $\$18$ to find the value of each grandchild's coins.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{c}=\blueE{56 \div 8} \times \redE{18} = \purpleD{\text{value of coins per grandchild}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal lengths, the first tape labeled c, and the second tape divided in 7 equal parts each labeled 18. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled value of coins per child. A curved bracket below the second tape is labeled 56 divided by 8 coins worth 18 dollars each.

hints.content: Equation | Meaning - | - $a=56$ | The total number of coins $b=56 \div 8$ | The number of coins per grandchild $c=56 \div 8 \times 18$ | The value, in dollars, of each grandchild's coins

question.content: The Starfish Diner serves $6$ customers. Each customer buys a Crispy Star for $3$ shells and a glass of milk for $1$ shell. One customer has a coupon, so their glass of milk is free.  **Match each equation to what it means in this context.**

hints.content: Let's build expressions from what we know.  If we add or subtract before we multiply or divide, we need parentheses around the addition or subtraction part.  We also use parentheses when we do a step on the right before a step on the left.
We can add to find the cost, in shells, per customer.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{a}=\maroonD{3}+\blueE{1}=\purpleD{\text{the cost per customer}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is larger and labeled 3. The second part is labeled 1. A curved bracket above the first part is labeled crispy star cost. A curved bracket above the second part is labeled milk cost. A curved bracket below the entire tape diagram is labeled cost per customer.

hints.content: Without the coupon, there would be $6$ customers who each spend the same amount. We can multiply to find the total before the coupon.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\goldE{b}=\purpleD{(3+1)} \times \redE{6}= \goldE{\text{the total cost before coupon}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 6 equal parts. Each part is labeled 3 plus 1 in parentheses. A curved bracket above the tape diagram is labeled total costs before coupon. A curved bracket below the entire tape diagram is labeled 6 customers paying 3 plus 1 in parentheses shells each.

hints.content: The coupon takes away the cost of a glass of milk, which is $1$ shell. We can subtract to find the cost after the coupon.  [[☃ image 1]]  ${c}=\goldE{(3+1) \times 6} -\tealE{1} = {\text{the total cost after coupon}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal length. The first tape is labeled 3 plus 1 in parentheses times 6. The second tape is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is larger and labeled C. The second part is labeled 1. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled total cost before coupon. A curved bracket below the first part of the second tape is labeled cost after coupon. A curved bracket below the second part of the second tape is labeled coupon.

hints.content: Equation | Meaning - | - $a=3+1$ | The cost per customer $b=(3+1) \times 6$ | The total cost before the coupon $c=(3+1) \times 6 -1$ | The total cost after the coupon

question.content: Mirri is traveling in a group of $8$ cats. Each cat needs $4$ liters of milk per day to maintain good morale. Mirri has a supply of $96$ liters of milk. Another cat has enough milk to last the group for $2$ days.  **Match each equation to what it means in this context.**

hints.content: Let's build expressions from what we know.  If we add or subtract before we multiply or divide, we need parentheses around the addition or subtraction part.  We also use parentheses when we do a step on the right before a step on the left.
We can multiply to find out how many liters of milk the cats drink in one day.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\redE{a}=\tealE{8}\times \goldE{4} = \redE{\text{liters of milk per day}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 4 equal parts. Each part is labeled 8. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled liters of milk per day. A curved bracket below the entire tape diagram is labeled 8 groups of 4 liters.

hints.content: We can divide $96$ (Mirri's total amount of milk) by the amount the cats drink in one day, to find the number of days Mirri's milk will last.     [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{b}=\purpleD{96} \div \redE{(8 \times 4)} = \blueE{\text{number of days Mirri's milk lasts}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of unequal length, a first tape labeled 96 and a shorter second tape labeled 8 times 4 in parentheses. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled Mirri’s milk. A curved bracket below the entire tape diagram is labeled question mark days of 8 times 4 in parentheses liters of milk per day.

hints.content: We can add to find the total number of days that Mirri's milk and the other cat's milk will last.    [[☃ image 1]]  $c=\blueE{96\div (8 \times 4)} + \maroonD{2}={\text{total days}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is labeled 96 divided by 8 times 4 in parentheses. The smaller, second part is labeled 2. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled total days. A curved bracket below the first part is labeled days Mirri’s milk lasts. A curved bracket below the second part is labeled days other milk lasts.

hints.content: Equation | Meaning - | - $a=8 \times 4$ | The number of liters of milk the cats drink in a day $b=96 \div (8 \times 4)$ | The number of days Mirri's milk will last $c=96 \div (8 \times 4) + 2$ | The number of days all the milk will last

question.content: A scout troop is planning to sing songs at a nursing home. They will sing $5$ songs that have $3$ verses each. The other $4$ songs have $2$ verses each.  **Match each equation to what it means in this context.**

hints.content: Let's build expressions from what we know.  If we add or subtract before we multiply or divide, we need parentheses around the addition or subtraction part.  We also use parentheses when we do a step on the right before a step on the left.

We can multiply to find the total number of verses in the longer songs, which have $3$ verses each.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\redE{a}=\tealE{5}\times \goldE{3} = \redE{\text{verses in songs with }3\text{ verses each}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 5 equal parts. Each part is labeled 3. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled, verses in longer songs. A curved bracket below the entire tape diagram is labeled, 5 groups of 3 verses.

hints.content: We can multiply to find the total number of verses in the shorter songs, which have $2$ verses each.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{b}=\purpleD{4} \times \maroonE{2} = \blueE{\text{verses in songs with }2\text{ verses each}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 4 equal parts. Each part is labeled 2. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled, verses in shorter songs. A curved bracket below the entire tape diagram is labeled, 4 groups of 2 verses.

hints.content: We can add to find the total number of verses in all of the songs.  [[☃ image 1]]  $c=(\redE{5\times 3})+(\blueE{4 \times 2})={\text{total verses}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is labeled, 5 times 3. The smaller, second part is labeled, 4 times 2. A curved bracket above the entire tape diagram is labeled total verses. A curved bracket below the first part is labeled, verses in longer songs. A curved bracket below the second part is labeled, verses in shorter songs.

hints.content: Equation | Meaning - | - $a=5 \times 3$ | The total number of verses in the longer songs $b=4 \times 2$ | The total number of verses in the shorter songs $c=(5 \times 3) + (4 \times 2)$ | The total number of verses in all the songs
